questions.text: What are the likely embryological phenomena resulting in this abnormality?

options.label: B
options.text: Failure of disintegration of central cells of Mullerian Eminence

options.label: C
options.text: Failure of two Mullerian ducts to unite

options.label: D
options.text: Failure of development of one Mullerian duct

questions.correct_answer: B. Failure of disintegration of central cells of Mullerian Eminence
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Failure of disintegration of central cells of Mullerian Eminence This results in an imperforate hymen. This results in hematocolpos, hematometra and hematosalpinx . The collected blood results in bulging of the membrane presenting as a tense, bulging swelling.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. This results in the complete absence of the uterus and vagina, thus there won’t be any menstrual cycles Option: C. This results in double uterovaginal canals Option: D. This results in uterus unicornis

questions.text: A 35-Year-old woman, G4A3P0L0, presented with bleeding PV during the second trimester. She was found to have undergone a spontaneous abortion. The fetal remains showed no chromosomal or genetic abnormality. The patient did not show any presence of antiphospholipid antibodies. USG showed two uterine cavities. Hysteroscopy showed the following. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hysteroscopic metroplasty The above patient has a septate uterus. The presence Septate uterus is not an indication of the operative intervention. The presence of infertility or dysmenorrhea or recurrent loss of pregnancy is an indication for surgical intervention. Usually done along with hysteroscopy, wherein the septa is resected via resectoscope or laser. It has a high success rate of 80-90%.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. The success rate is lesser than that of hysteroscopic metroplasty, with lesser postoperative morbidity with a shorter hospital stay. Vaginal delivery is not possible in abdominal metroplasty Option: C. Done in cervical incompetency Option: D. Done in APLA syndrome

questions.text: The septate uterus can be diagnosed by all the following investigations, except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HSG HSG: HSG is mainly preferred in uterine anomalies but it cannot distinguish between a septate and bicornuate uterus. This is because in order to distinguish between the 2, the uterine fundus should be visible. Hysterosalpingography (HSG)—cannot reliably differentiate between a septate and a bicornuate/arcuate uterus. If the angle of divergence between the two uterine cavities is < 75°, the defect is most likely to be the septate uterus. If the angle of divergence is >75° but < 105° a diagnosis cannot be made.

Highyeild:

IOC FOR MULLERIAN MALFORMATIONS : 3 D USG / MRI GOLD STANDARD FOR MULLERIAN MALFORMATIONS: HYSTEROSCOPY AND LAPAROSCOPY. HSG HAS NO ROLE IN DIFFERENTIATING BICORNUATE AND DIDELPHYS

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Transvaginal USG: It is the best method to distinguish between a septate and bicornuate uterus. As it reveals the shape of the fundal contour. Option C: MRI: Expensive technique but provides the most accurate diagnosis. Option D: Hysteroscopy: It is both diagnostic and curative.

questions.text: You are evaluating a patient with Mullerian duct anomaly. Failure of fusion along the whole length of the Mullerian duct will result in
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Uterus didelphys Option A: Failure of Mullerian duct fusion will result in uterine didelphys

Highyeild:

It is a condition where there is a failure of fusion along the whole length of the Mullerian duct It results in 2 vaginas, 2 cervices, and 2 uteri Bicornuate uterus / Uterus bicornis In this condition only the lower part of the ducts fuse leaving the cornua separate, so always there is a single vagina Uterus bicornis bicollis Here vagina is fused but the cervix has a Uterus bicornis unicollis Here vagina and cervix are fused, i.e. single vagina, single cervix but 2 uteri.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B : Improper formation of fundus where there is fundal indentation. Option C: Failure of resorption of septa between the 2 fused Mullerian ducts. Option D: Improper fusion of Mullerian ducts leads to a bicornuate uterus.

questions.text: Heavy periods, chronic pelvic pain, and painful intercourse. All of her pregnancies were spontaneous abortions in the first trimester. A hysterosalpingogram (HSG) she just had as part of the evaluation for recurrent abortion showed a large uterine septum. You have recommended surgical repair of the uterus. Of the patient’s symptoms, which is most likely to be corrected by resection of the uterine septum?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Habitual abortion Habitual abortion is the most important indication for surgical treatment of women who have a double uterus . The abortion rate in women who have a double uterus is two to three times greater than that of the general population. Therefore, women who present with habitual abortion should be evaluated to detect a possible septate uterus. Hysterosalpingography, hysteroscopy, ultrasound, CT, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) are all potentially useful imaging modaliƟes in this investigation. Dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and menometrorrhagia are not caused by the presence of a uterine septum.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis from the following image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Unicornuate uterus The diagram given above appears banana-shaped without the rounded fundus and triangular-shaped uterine cavity hence it is a unicornuate uterus.

options.label: A
options.text: The given image is of 3D USG

options.label: B
options.text: The given image is of a 3D MRI

options.label: C
options.text: The given image is of CECT

options.label: D
options.text: The given image is of saline infused hysterosalpingogram.

questions.correct_answer: A. The given image is of 3D USG
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The given image is of 3D USG It is an identification based question where in we have to identify the modality used. Since the cortical bones cannot be visualized its not a CT. In HSG only the inside of uterus is visualized An MRI of the uterus also has a different appearance .

questions.text: All the statements about the following image are true, except

options.label: A
options.text: If A measures less than 4 cm and angle B measures less than 60° the diagnosis is septate uterus, on laparoscopy single fundus is seen.

options.label: B
options.text: It is to be treated by septoplasty If the septum extends to 30% of the septal cavity

options.label: C
options.text: It is the most common Mullerian abnormality

options.label: D
options.text: Most common obstetric abnormality associated with it is malpresentation.

questions.correct_answer: D. Most common obstetric abnormality associated with it is malpresentation.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Most common obstetric abnormality associated with it is malpresentation. The given image shows a bicornuate uterus on HSG . It is associated with miscarriage. It is treated by metroplasty

Extraedge:

septate uterus mc uterine anomaly mc uterine anomaly associated with recurrent abortion mc uterine anomaly associated with infertility management is hysteroscopic resection of the uterus

questions.text: While evaluating a 30-Year-old woman for infertility, you diagnose a bicornuate uterus. You explain that additional testing is necessary because of the woman’s increased risk of congenital anomalies in which organ system?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Urinary Failed fusion of the Müllerian ducts can give rise to several types of uterine anomalies, of which the bicornuate uterus is a representative type. This condition is associated with a higher risk of obstetric complications, such as an increase in the rate of second-trimester abortion and premature labou If these pregnancies go to term, malpresentation such as breech and a transverse lie is more frequent. Also, prolonged labour (probably attributed to inadequate muscle development in the uterus), increased bleeding, and a higher incidence of fetal anomalies caused by defective implantation of the placenta all occur more commonly than in normal pregnancies. An intravenous pyelogram or urinary tract ultrasound is mandatory in patients with Müllerian anomalies since approximately 30% of patients with Müllerian anomalies have coexisting congenital urinary tract anomalies. In the bicornuate uterus (termed uterus bicornis unicollis), there is a double uterine cavity (bicornis) and a single cervix (unicollis) with a normal vagina.

Highyeild:

Ø Associated Problems with uterine anomalies Renal: renal unilateral agenesis, ectopic and horseshoe-shaped, duplication of collecting system, hydronephrosis. Skeletal: Scoliosis, hemivertebrae, vertebral fusion

Extraedge:

septate uterus mc uterine anomaly mc uterine anomaly associated with recurrent abortion mc uterine anomaly associated with infertility management is hysteroscopic resection of the uterus

questions.text: Your patient delivers a 3kg male infant at term. On physical examination, the baby has normal-appearing male external genitalia. However, the scrotum is empty. No testes are palpable in the inguinal canals. At 6 months of age, the boy’s testes still have not descended. A pelvic ultrasound shows the testes in the pelvis, and there appears to be a uterus present as well. The presence of a uterus in an otherwise phenotypically normal male is owing to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lack of Müllerian-inhibiting factor Müllerian structures appear during embryonic development in both males and females. Female gonads do not secrete Müllerian-inhibiting substances (MIS), and the Müllerian structures persist . Male testes secrete MIF, which causes regression ofMüllerian structures. Anything that prevents MIF secretion in genetic males will result in the persistence of Müllerian structures into the postnatal period . Persons who appear to be normal males but who possess a uterus and fallopian tubes have such a failure of the Müllerian-inhibiting factor. Their karyotype is 46, XY, testes are present, and testosterone production is normal.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B: lack of testosterone causes female external genitalia to develop Option C: no role In initial development. Option D: absence of the SRY gene causes gonadal differentiation in the ovary

Extraedge:

septate uterus mc uterine anomaly mc uterine anomaly associated with recurrent abortion mc uterine anomaly associated with infertility management is hysteroscopic resection of the uterus

questions.text: A 16-Year-old girl presented with complaints of non-attainment of menarche. She gave a history of cyclical abdominal pain. What findings do you not expect in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: A transverse vaginal septum on USG

options.label: C
options.text: A bulge anteriorly on Digital Rectal Exam(DRE)

questions.correct_answer: D. A uterine septum on USG
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A uterine septum on USG A uterine septum does not impede the flow of menstrual blood . Cyclical abdominal pain is indicative of normal menstrual cycles with an outflow tract obstruction

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Hematometra (collection of blood in the uterus) occurs when there is an outflow obstruction at or below the level of the cervix Option: B. A complete transverse vaginal septum impedes blood flow during menstruation Option: C. The bulge is due to hematocolpos due to a lower vaginal obstruction such as imperforate hymen

questions.text: A 23-Year-old G3A3P0L0 presented to the OPD with a history of heavy menstrual bleeding. Following abdominal examination, a hysterosalpingogram was taken which revealed the following. What anomaly is the result of the following clinical picture?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Uterus didelphys This results from a lack of fusion of the two Mullerian ducts resulting in two uteri and a vagina. This can result in recurrent pregnancy loss and menorrhagia. The hysterosalpingogram shows distinct two uterine cavities with two cervix Uterus didelphys has two vaginas

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. A septate uterus can result in recurrent pregnancy loss but HSG shows an intervening septum. Option: C. An arcuate uterus shows only a single uterine cavity Option: D . It shows only one fallopian tube with a single cornua with a smaller than average uterus

questions.text: A 16-Year-old of normal stature comes to you with primary infertility. She has Tanner stage 4 breast development with axillary and pubic hair. Her external genitalia is normal but her vagina is short with the absent cervix. You order investigations and conclude with a diagnosis. Her mother is concerned about the chances of fertility in her daughter. Which option will you suggest?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Surrogacy Diagnosis: MRKH (breast development present but axillary and pubic hair, Normal external genitalia, blind vagina) They have no uterus, hence IVF with surrogacy is indicated.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: indicated in the septate uterus Option B: the patient has XX karyotype, and most of them have functional ovaries. Hence donor oocytes aren't needed. Option D : cervix and uterus are absent

questions.text: A 19-Year-old patient came with complaints of primary amenorrhea. She had well-developed breasts and pubic hair. However, there was an absence of a vagina and uterus. The likely diagnosis is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mullerian agenesis The phenotype of the patient is female: This rules out Klinefelter syndrome (47 X XY) as in Klinefelter syndrome phenotype of the patient resembles a male and not female. The presence of well-developed breast and pubic hair and the absence of a uterus and vagina rules out Turner's syndrome and gonadal agenesis because in both these conditions gonads (ovary) although present streak. Hence levels of estrogen are low and so secondary sexual characteristics are not developed or less developed. Here the internal genital organs are present but not well developed due to a lack of deficiency of estrogen.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions do the ovaries function normally?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome Ovaries develop from the genital ridge , whereas fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix and upper part of the vagina are formed by the Mullerian duct. In mullerian agenesis which is also called Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser syndrome, the fallopian tube, uterus, cervix and upper part of the vagina are absent and not ovaries. Ovaries are normally functioning.

questions.text: The ideal age for the repair of vaginal agenesis is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Before marriage Repair of vaginal agenesis (seen in testicular feminization syndrome and Mayer Rokitansky-Kuster Hauser syndrome) is done by vaginoplasty. Vaginoplasty should only be performed when the girl is just married or about to be married. Techniques: Construction of artificial vagina by Mc Indoe operation (procedure of choice). Williams vaginoplasty – creates a vaginal pouch from the skin of labia majora. Vaginoplasty with amnion graft

Highyeild:

Comparison of Müllerian Agenesis and Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome Presentation Müllerian Agenesis Androgen Insensitivity Inheritance pattern Sporadic X-linked recessive Karyotype 46,XX 46,XY Breast development Yes Yes Axillary and pubic hair Yes No Uterus No No Gonad Ovary Testis Testosterone Female levels Male levels Associated anomalies Yes No
